text:
JACKIE PETERSON: I'd like to
introduce our speaker today. Once again, I'm Jackie Peterson. And I'm the program manager
for the genetics and genomics

program here at the Stanford
Center for Health Education. I want to thank you all for
joining me and our fantastic

speaker today. Today I have Professor
Ami Bhatt with me.

Ami Bhatt is an
associate professor at Stanford University in
the departments of medicine and genetics.

A physician scientist
with a strong interest in microbial genomics
and metagenomics,

she received her MD And PhD from
the University of California San Francisco.

She joined the faculty at
Stanford University in 2014. In addition to
carrying out research

at Stanford University,
Professor Bhatt has active
collaborations worldwide, including in Nigeria
and South Africa.

She co-founded Global
Oncology, and serves as a director for
Global Oncology

for Stanford's Center for
Innovation in Global Health. Her team's research
program seeks

to illuminate the interplay
between the microbial environment and host clinical
factors in human diseases.

Her laboratory studies
strain level dynamics of the microbiome to understand
how microbial genomes change

over time and predict
the functional output of microbiomes. She is keenly interested in how
microbes talk to one another

and to host cells, and how to
leverage this understanding to improve health
and treat diseases.

Thank you for being here. And I'll now pass it
over to Dr. Bhatt. DR. AMI BHATT: Thank you so
much for the introduction.

And thank you all for taking the
time to spend an hour with me today thinking about
the microbiome.

I want you to take a look
at this photomicrograph. What is a photomicrograph? A photomicrograph is basically
a microscopic picture

that one can take. What do you see? And what do you think
you're looking at?

Well for me, what I see is
an incredibly complicated set

of communications
that are going on. This happens to be the
cross section of a colon.

The colon is the largest
part of our intestine. It's at the very distal
part or the last part

of our digestive tract. And what it has is
on the right side of the picture in the
bottom right-hand corner,

these blue-stained nuclei. That's actually the
host side of the colon or the colonic tissue itself.

This happens to be from a mouse. But a human colon would
look very similar.

On the top left-hand side
of the image, what you see are a lot of little tiny
dots and rods and spirals.

These are bacteria. These are the bacteria
that are absolutely teeming in our intestines.

And between the two, you
see two greenish layers, they're slightly different
from one another.

And these are the thick and
thin layers of the mucus. This mucus is made by the
host and separates bacteria

from the host. But as you can tell if you
take a really close look at that mucus, you can
see tiny little bacteria

that are actually invading
that demilitarized zone.

So we know that we are
covered in microbes, filled with microbes, and that
they are incredibly

important to our health. And over the course
of the next 40 minutes or so, we're going to talk
about some of the things

that we and others have done
to investigate this incredibly interesting relationship.

Now, I would argue that
microbiome science is actually a really old field,
even though many of you

may think of it as kind
of a Johnny-come-lately. In fact, if you take a look
at this text from about 30

before the Common
Era, this was written by Marcus Varro, who was
writing books on agriculture.

He noted that, "Certain minute
animals, invisible to the eye, breed there, and,
borne by the air,

reach the inside of the body
by ways of the mouth and nose, and cause diseases which
are difficult to be rid of."

This is, I think, actually
the first description in the literature that we know
of of bacteria and viruses,

tiny little animals
that we can't see that can move
from place to place, and when transmitted,
can cause problems.

But it really wasn't until
the late 1600s and early 1700s

until we really had a
better understanding of what these microbes actually were.

Pictured on the left here
is Anthony van Leeuwenhoek. He was a famous draper
and nobleman in Europe.

And what he was really
interested in doing was figuring out the
weaves of different cloths.

Now as you know when
you're weaving cloth, the more threads you
have in a small area, the better the cloth.

And to be able to assess
how many threads there were in a given, let's
say, square inch of cloth,

Anthony van Leeuwenhoek
had been playing around with trying to develop better
and better ways to magnify

the drapery. And what he ended up
doing was actually developing what we now know
of as the light microscope.

Now, having this
cool tool, he decided to not only look
at drapery but also at other interesting
things around town.

And so he ended up
looking at pond scum. He looked at the gunk that
was in between his teeth. Remember, that
this was in an era
before common dental practices. And what he found amazed him.

He found all kinds of different
organisms-- big and small, rod shaped, circular, spiral.

Some were sedentary. Some moved. And he described these as
tiny little animals, again,

or "animalcules." Pictured on the right
are actual drawings that Leeuwenhoek drew of
these different bacteria

that he was seeing. And I would argue
that this was actually one of the first times
anybody ever saw a bacterium

with their own eyes.  Of course over the subsequent
years, especially in the 1800s,

people started to be
able to culture bacteria. They could get bacteria, put
them on these Petri dishes,

as you see on the
left, and grow them up into numbers in the millions
and billions and even trillions.

They then would
take these bacteria, put them on a glass
slide, and stain them with different stains.

And what you see on the
right side of this picture is a gram stain,
which is a classic way to describe bacteria.

Some of you who are
scientifically oriented in the audience may know
that we describe bacteria as staining gram positive
or gram negative.

And so for a long
period of time, this is what bacteriology
was all about. We collected samples.

We cultured them on special
media or these Petri dishes. We then put them on
slides, stained them,

and described how they
looked under a microscope.

But of course, our ability
to enumerate microbes was limited at that time. We didn't know how
to grow all bacteria.

We didn't know what
they liked to eat. Some of them are
totally interdependent and therefore can't be
separated from one another.

And some of them
don't even stain with these specific
stains that we have. And so a huge
revolution in the field

arrived with the advent of
next-generation DNA sequencing. Where suddenly, instead
of describing a bacteria

by looking at how
it looked, in terms of its shape and
its staining, we were able to sequence all of
its genetic code or DNA in As,

Cs, Ts, and Gs,
and then describe the reads or the
words of DNA that we

found in a given sample. In so doing, we were
able to not only measure

one bacteria at a time that
we could isolate and culture, but without having to isolate
and culture bacteria at all,

we could read all
kinds of little words and then assign them
to different bacteria.

Now, this revolution really
only started in real zest about 20 years ago.

And at this point,
our field is centered around this central
type of approach.

We collect stool samples
from humans or other animals. We can also collect other types
of samples where microbes live,

such as the skin,
the mouth, the nares. We then extract DNA
from that sample.

And then we analyze the
sequencing data that we get or all of the different
DNA words that come out.

And we try to ask
questions like, who's there in this community? We also want to be able
to ask what are they doing

and what do they make. To analyze these
huge amounts of data

that we're able to
generate now, we obviously need efficient ways to
analyze this big data.

And for that reason,
me and others develop computational
pipelines that enable us to turn billions
of pieces of information
into orderly graphs.

So over the course of
the past 20 or so years, the microbiome field
has learned a lot.

We know that we have
microbes all over our body. We know we have lots of
microbes in our mouth,

our skin the colon, and
the vagina, for example. We know that as pictured
here, the bacterial types

that are present in these
different communities are different. And they're not only
different within our bodies.

But our mouths are very
different from our spouses' mouths or our kids' mouths.

And so we know that the
microbiome varies a lot from individual to individual.

By the numbers, we know that we
have approximately 10 trillion microbes in or on our bodies.

They can make up up to
3% of our body mass. And there are at least
as many microbial cells

as there are human
cells in our body. So I would argue that we're
almost equal parts them and us.

We also know that there
are 10 to 100 times as many microbial genes as
there are human genes in a given

human, which suggests that
if we take a look at this from the standpoint
of genetic diversity

that is contributed
to our bodies, bacteria do a lot more
of the heavy lifting than our own cells do.

But do these bacteria,
viruses, fungi, et cetera

really make a difference
in our health? The answer to that
is absolutely.

Scores of studies
have demonstrated that bacteria that live
within the large intestine

can do a variety of
different things, such as extract
nutrients from our food.

This is certainly
true for us, where it is estimated that about 4%
of the nutrients that we absorb

into our bodies are actually
not digestible initially by us, but rather predigested
for us by our bacteria.

But it's even more true
in animals like elephants, which are pictured here.

Elephants and other
ruminant animals, such as cows as you probably
know, are entirely herbivorous.

So they eat plants. And plants are really
hard to break down. Their fibers are very complex.

And mammals don't
actually possess a lot of enzymes that
enable us to break apart

these complex fibers, which
are sugars stuck together in a long chain.

Elephants actually
depend on bacteria that live within their guts to
do some of that heavy lifting.

And you might ask
yourself, well, how did those bacteria get
there in the first place? Well, it turns out
that baby elephants

have to eat the poop
of adult elephants within their herd to
essentially inoculate

their guts with these bacteria. It's been nicely demonstrated
that baby elephants that

are kept away from
other adult elephants actually runt, which means
that they don't grow properly,

probably because they're
not able to extract enough nutrients
from their food.

Mice research in animals has
also demonstrated that you cannot only lose weight,
because you don't have the right

bacteria in your gut
if you're an elephant. You can also gain
weight, if you have, let's say, the wrong bacteria
in your gut, if you're a mouse.

In very nice research that was
done by Peter Turnbaugh when he was at WashU St.
Louis, he and Jeff Gordon

demonstrated that if you fed
skinny mice poop from fat mice,

that was actually
enough to make them better at extracting
nutrients from their food and make them fatter.

Now of course, this
is very compelling. It's been followed up with
interesting human studies. And this finding hasn't
recapitulated well

in humans to date. But it's certainly
a nice example of how our bacteria are doing
a whole lot more than just
hanging on for the ride.

producing important
vitamins, like B12 for us, and even regulating immunity.

Indeed, we know that over the
first approximately three years of life, the microbiome and
our adaptive immune system,

meaning our B cells and our
T cells, actually co-develop. And early microbial
exposures in kids

probably have a large role
in shaping the immune systems of these children.

This has been well
demonstrated in animal models. And we know that
animals for example, that are born germ free
or without any bacteria,

actually have a whole host
of immunological deficits.

Now, your early life
isn't the only time where you can affect
your microbiome. We know that dietary
choices throughout life

dramatically impact
the gut microbiome, be it from formula
versus breast milk--

human breast milk actually
contains a large variety of human milk
oligosaccharides-- once again,

oligosaccharides
are like fibers. They're chains of
sugars put together. And it turns out that these
human milk oligosaccharides are

not digestible by you or me. They're actually only
digestible by certain bacteria

that live in the baby's gut. And so the gut
microbiomes of babies that are formula
fed are actually

quite different from the
gut microbiomes of babies that are breastfed

There are also
choices that we make throughout life that continue
to impact our microbiome.

For example, pictured
here are onions. Onions or alliums, which is
what the name of the family is,

contain a huge amount of
fructooligosaccharides, again, another type of fiber
that can actually

change the composition
of the microbiome.

What we know is that the
microbiome changes over time. And that from
infancy to childhood

to adulthood, when people
start to experience diseases, the microbiome can shift.

We know that all kinds of
things ranging from solid food feeding to having diseases,
such as obesity or diabetes,

can impact the gut microbiome
quite dramatically.

And so in our lab, what
we are keen to understand is how we might be able
to save cancer patient

lives by understanding and
manipulating the microbiome.

In particular in our lab, we
focus on hematopoietic cell transplantation, or HCT.

As many of you know,
HCT is a therapy for people with refractory or
relapsed leukemia and lymphoma.

It can be a very effective way
to treat very aggressive blood cancers.

But it comes at a high price. It's a complicated therapy
that involves blasting people

with anticancer drugs or
chemotherapy, plus or minus radiation.

We give them so much of
these DNA damaging agents that their rapidly
dividing cells, including

all of their
progenitor blood cells, which are called
hematopoietic cells, actually can't recover well.

So what we do is we get
hematopoietic stem cells from a donor and introduce
them into the patient.

Those hematopoietic stem cells
will eventually take hold. And they will differentiate into
red blood cells, white blood

cells, and platelets.  Now, while the transplant is
an incredible therapy that

has saved a lot of
lives, it turns out that it has a very high
mortality rate as well.

In fact, about 20%
to 30% of patients who receive a hematopoietic
cell transplant actually

die in the first year after
their transplantation. And what was really alarming to
me was that only about a third

of these patients,
37%, die of a relapse of their original
cancer, which means

that 63% die of
treatment-related complications, of which
infection is actually

a big part of that pie.  Many of these
non-cancer outcomes

that happen to our
transplant patients that cause death are associated
with changes in the microbiome,

as indicated here
by the asterisks. And so the open
question that our lab

tried to tackle a
few years ago was how does the microbiome impact
infectious complications

of hematopoietic
cell transplantation. It seemed reasonable
to think that since we

have so many
bacteria in our gut, maybe those bacteria were
impacting whether or not people got infections
after transplant.

This work was done as a
collaboration between Tessa

Andermann, a former
immunocompromised host infectious disease
fellow in my lab, and Fiona Tamburini, a former
graduate student in my lab.

And what we focused
on was trying to bring precision clinical
microbiology to the table
in the sequencing era.  So this starts with a case.

At Stanford, we
actually saw a patient who was a 39-year-old
woman with a B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

She underwent a transplant and
was actually doing quite well. Unfortunately, 37 days
after her transplant,

she developed fevers and chills. And a blood culture showed
the growth of the bacterium

Staphylococcus epidermidis. Our question was, where did
this infection come from.

Tessa and Fiona knew
that many gut microbes

can cause infections,
for example, E. coli. But Staph epi, as
the name implies,

is actually usually
a skin commensal, meaning it lives on
the skin of people.

However, in looking
at gut microbiome data from many of our
patients, the two of them had noticed that organisms
like Staph epidermidis,

while very rare in the gut
microbiomes of healthy people like me, can actually be quite
prevalent in our transplant

patients, probably
because they've been exposed to a lot
of medications that can alter their microbiome.

And so Tessa and Fiona asked the
question, is the gut microbiome a reservoir of pathogens
in this patient population.

Meaning, do they have
bacteria in their colons, as pictured in the top part of
the diagram, that can make it

into the bloodstream, as
pictured in the bottom part of the diagram, and
cause an infection.

To address this question, Fiona
wrote a very straightforward bioinformatic tool to help
us analyze all of these data.

I won't go into detail
here, but I'll just give you the name of it,
which is StrainSifter. And what it does
is it enables us

to identify whether the bacteria
in the bloodstream that we're able to identify
is the same as one

of the bacteria in
the gut microbiome.  When we applied this
method on our patient who

had that bloodstream
infection, this is actually what her gut
microbiome looked like one day prior to her infection.

This is a stacked bar histogram. So on the y-axis is
the relative abundance of different bacteria.

So a big chunk of section
means that there's a lot of that bacteria. And a skinny sliver
means that there's less.

And what you can see is that
Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is in the purple and
highlighted by a black box,

was actually present in the gut
microbiome of this individual prior to her infection.

Now you may say, well,
we've got our smoking gun. Staph epi was in the gut. That's the same bug that
caused her infection.

But we can't be so
fast to conclude that, because Staph epidermidis is
present on almost all of us.

And in fact, each one of us
harbors many, many strains, different strains of Staph epi.

And so while we found
Staph epi in her gut, it didn't mean that it
was the same one that was in her bloodstream.

Using Fiona's
StrainSifter tool however, we're able to identify how
closely related organisms are

to one another. And for patient 13, which
is the patient we're talking about
today, what we were

able to show was
that in the blue box, the stool sample that we
had for her was actually

indistinguishable
from the bloodstream isolate in terms
of this bacteria. And this is represented on
a phylogenetic tree, which

is a way to measure evolutionary
distance between organisms.

When there's a straight
line between them, it basically means
that they're identical.

Now, we found that not
only Staph epi infections could originate in the gut. We found that many
other organisms also

seem to be present in the gut
microbiome prior to patients getting infections.

This ranged from organisms
like Enterococcus faecium and Klebsiella
pneumoniae to organisms

like E. coli and Strep mitis. Of course, we didn't find
this for every organism.

For a common bloodstream
infection called Staph aureus, we didn't in this
particular study

find any evidence
of gut colonization.

Taken together, what we were
able to find was that about 40% of bloodstream infections
in this patient population

are traceable to the gut
microbiome, which led us

to our next question,
which is if pathogens are present in the gut
microbiome of these patients,

well how do they get
there in the first place. Where do people catch these
pathogenic microbes from?

What we know about
this patient population is that they're in the
hospital for a long time. They're very sick.

And so we surmise
that perhaps patients were catching these
pathogenic microbes

either from the hospital
setting or from one another. And so we inspected
whether patient A,

as represented on
the left, could transmit their
microbes to patient B, as pictured on the right.

And if this was the
case, might things like being in the same room or
the same ward at the same time

be risk factors for this?  So to ask and address
this question,

Ben, Siranosian, a former
graduate student in the lab, teamed up with a professor
of statistics and genetics,

and Niaz Banaei, who is the head
of our clinical microbiology group.

And what they found was
actually interesting. We studied hundreds of patients
who had been on the same ward

over the course of
about 15 months. And I'll highlight
just a couple of cases

that we thought
were interesting. First, an overall finding. Most patients don't seem
to be catching microbes

from their neighbors that much. And so we found evidence
of transmission. But it was rare.

This is an example of
transmission of an Enterococcus faecium, which is a pathogen
that can cause bad bloodstream

infections. And oftentimes, this organism
is quite drug resistant. Now on the top part of
the diagram, once again,

you have a stacked bar
histogram describing the relative abundance
of different bacteria

in that top
patient's microbiome. And you can see that top
patient is pretty much filled with Enterococcus
faecium, as highlighted

in blue. If you take a look
above that diagram, you can see a skinny bar.

And that bar indicates when
the top patient actually overlapped with the bottom
patient as a roommate

or in the hospital
at the same time. Well, you can't
see it very well.

What we found was that
the blue organism that is present in the top
individual actually seems

to appear in the
bottom individual, albeit at a low relative
abundance, only 0.4%, shortly

after the time period where
the two are roommates, suggesting that there
was a direct transmission

event between the top individual
and the bottom individual. Put another way, our
bottom patient actually

caught Enterococcus faecium
from the top individual in their gut microbiome.

And there, the gut
microbiome, E. faecium, could lie in wait, until
there was an opportune time

to get into the bloodstream
and cause an infection.

We not only found
this for pathogens like Enterococcus faecium. We actually also found
this for good microbes,

such as Hungatella hathewayi. Now, Hungatella hathewayi
is a commensal organism

that is thought to
actually be very anti-inflammatory and
probably healthy in our guts.

And once again, as you
can see in this image, we've got one patient on
the top, second patient on the bottom.

You can see that
there was transmission of Hungatella hathewayi
from the top patient

to the bottom patient. And that happened shortly
after they were roommates.

Interestingly,
this bottom patient did have Hungatella hathewayi
eye at the very beginning

of this time course. And when we noticed
that, we thought, oh, well maybe
these patients just had the same organism
to begin with.

However, when we compared
the Hungatella hathewayi that the bottom patient had
at day 0 versus at day 58,

we found that those
were totally different, meaning that the original
Hungatella hathewayi

that the bottom patient had
been replaced by the one that it got from its roommate.

Put together, what we
were able to demonstrate

was that we could use
strain resolved evidence that gut commensals and
pathogens can be transmitted

horizontally between
adults, meaning that they can get passed from
adult to adult in this hospital

setting.  So if patients can
catch pathogens,

a question then follows. If I want to prevent
infections, and I know that infections
in the bloodstream

often originate
in the gut, and I know that patients can catch
these microbes in their gut,

how might we manage
patient microbiomes to prevent acquisition
of these pathogens

and eventual outgrowth of them? To answer this question,
several members of my lab

have worked on a
series of projects where we have tried to modify
the microbiome using techniques

that range from fecal
microbiota transplant to antibiotics to prebiotics.

So there are three
main ways that you can change a microbiome
in broad brush strokes.

One is to use antibiotics
that kill certain bacteria. The next is to use probiotics
or live bacterial therapies,

a very extreme version of
which is fecal microbiota transplantation,
which many of you

have probably heard of, where
you give the feces of one individual to another.

The third way that you can
change the microbiome that should come as no
surprise to you given that we talked about it
earlier in the seminar

is prebiotics or fibers. It turns out that
we can give fibers

that selectively feed certain
components of our microbes over others. And this can also be a way to
remodel the gut microbiome.

In our first work
in this space, we worked on fecal microbiota
transplantation. And this was a collaboration
with Libby Holman's group

at the Mass General Hospital. While when we do FMT
we don't do what's pictured on the left, which
is an image of two people's

colons stuck together,
what we actually do is something more like
what's pictured on the right.

We take feces. We filter them. We test people
extensively to make sure they don't have pathogens
that we can transmit.

And then we can package them
into things like these capsules or so-called "crapsules."

Patients then take 15 of these
pills one day, another 15 of these pills the next day.

And that's usually enough to
actually colonize their gut microbiomes, at least in the
short term with these microbes.

While I won't go into
details of the findings that we had in this
study, I'll summarize it by saying that we found that the
microbes that the donor gives

to the recipient
through this FMT colonized well in the recipient
for the first few weeks.

But in the long
term, they end up getting washed out
by other organisms, suggesting that short-term
colonization is actually

quite prevalent, but long-term
changes in the microbiome are actually hard to achieve
with a two-time fecal

microbiota transplant.  Another way to
change the microbiota

is actually to use prebiotics,
as we've discussed. And Tessa Andermann,
along with Andrew Rezvani

carried out a prebiotic
pilot trial, where we gave a prebiotic-- in this
case fructooligosaccharide,

which you'll remember is
a fiber that is commonly found in plants such as onions.

We gave this
fructooligosaccharide to patients undergoing
a transplantation.

We did a dose escalation
single-arm study. 15 patients were enrolled.

And the FOS, or
fructooligosaccharide, was tolerated well.

While this was going
on, Tessa collected stool samples and blood
samples from these patients,

as well as control patients
who were not receiving the fructooligosaccharides.

While we found no major
differences in the gut microbiome between
the individuals who got the FOS and
people who did not,

we did find that
fructooligosaccharides were probably
important for producing

this type of small
molecule called "butyrate." Fructooligosaccharides,
once again,

are these complex sugars. And bacteria can metabolize
them into tiny little pieces,

which are called "butyrate,"
short chain fatty acids. And butyrate had
been demonstrated

by others in the
field to actually be very anti-inflammatory. In this particular
example, butyrate

could ameliorate or improve
graft-versus-host disease, which is an
inflammatory disorder.

The way butyrate
works is it actually

can trigger T
regulatory cells, which are an inflammation suppressing
cell type in the immune system,

to proliferate. And so we had surmised
that FOS might increase

the abundance of T-regs, these
anti-inflammatory T cells, in the patients who got it.

And indeed, we found-- as
is outlined in the red box-- that patients who got FOS
had more FOXP3 CD3 cells,

which are T regulatory
cells, than control patients.

So we've talked about
probiotics or FMT. We've talked about prebiotics.

The other arm of this
three-legged stool is antibiotics. Now typically, we
think of antibiotics

as doing harm to the microbiome. But a series of studies done
over the past approximately

five decades have suggested
that giving patients non-absorbable antibiotics,
meaning antibiotics that

can act on the inside
of the intestine but don't get into
our bloodstream, can actually improve
the outcomes of patients

who are undergoing hematopoietic
cell transplantation. So Jen Whangbo, who is a
physician scientist in Boston

at Boston Children's Hospital,
and Chris Severyn who is a pediatric hematologist
and oncologist in my lab,

teamed up to do a
randomized controlled trial of this practice of
gut decontamination

in pediatric patients undergoing
allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation.

What they did was
actually give-- once again, some patients
that got decontamination. And other patients did not get
any, so they were the controls.

And they look for differences
in the patient populations. Now, this was a
very small study.

And while this did not reach
statistical significance, we did find that the patients
who got gut decontamination had

many fewer bloodstream
infections than the patients who did not get the antibiotics,
which suggests that these gut

decontamination antibiotics
might be clearing out some of those pathogens
that we've demonstrated

can be present in
the gut microbiomes of these individuals. Chris was further
able to demonstrate

that in every case in the
non-gut decontamination arm or those controls where
they had an infection,

the infection was traceable
back to the gut microbiome.

Taken together,
what we found was that this is days after
transplant on the x-axis. And the percent of people
who had a bloodstream

infection with concomitant
colonization of the gut with that organism-- we see that there
is a big difference,

a visible difference
between those individuals who had no gut
decontamination versus those who had gut decontamination,
which suggests that gut

decontamination may decrease the
incidence of these bloodstream infections.

So coming back to
this picture, I hope I've convinced you that
we and others have developed

exquisitely sensitive
methods to figure out who's there in the microbiome.

And we know that measuring
microbes at the strain level matters, because
there are millions

of different strains of,
for example, an E. coli out there in the world.

We talked about precision
clinical microbiology in the sequencing era. We talked about how we can
track microbes between patients.

And finally, we
talked about how we

can modify the microbiome using
fecal microbiota transplants, antibiotics, and prebiotics.
So that's what we've done.

What are we doing next? I thought I would give you
a bit of a sneak preview into the work that
we're up to now.

And as we look to
the future, we have become extremely interested
in co-opting microbial

communication systems,
so that we can precisely manipulate medicine.

When we look at this figure,
part of what we're trying to do is really zoom in to the
bacterial side of things.

And when we zoom in, I imagine
a scene like this is going on, where you have wonderful and
exciting conversations going

on between bacteria, and
not only between bacteria, but maybe also even
between bacteria and us.

This is actually
not so far fetched. We know from previous
research that microbes

can use small
molecules or chemicals to talk within species. So they can talk to their own.

They can talk between
species and actually also engage in bacterial
warfare, killing others off.

And they can use these
small molecules to even talk between domains
of life, meaning between bacteria and humans.

This small molecule collection
of communication signals

has been exploited
extensively in what I call "nature's medicine cabinet."

Many of the drugs that
we use in modern medicine today, ranging from the
chemotherapy, doxorubicin,

to the topical antimicrobial
agent, bacitracin, are actually derived
from bacteria.

But while these small
molecules or chemicals

have been well mined for their
use in precision medicine,

proteins have not
been so well mined. Proteins however are optimal
signaling biomolecules.
They're diverse. They're very highly specific. They're biocompatible.

And we can synthesize
them scalably. And so the question that
we now have in our lab is, might microbes use small
proteins to communicate.

A greatly enabling
piece of work that

has allowed us to peer into
this new and exciting realm of microprotein-based
communication

was carried out by Hila Sberro,
a former postdoc in the lab. Using computational
biology approaches

and evolutionary theory,
she was able to discover thousands of hidden small
proteins in microbial genomes.

In total, she discovered
about 4,500 new families. Most of these are
of unknown function.

And about 30% of them
we predict are involved in cell-cell communication.

So as we move forward, what
we hope to be able to do is take this blue
bacteria on the left,

identify small proteins that it
makes, like these pink blobs, figure out what host
cells or human cells

they communicate with, as
pictured in the middle, and eventually exploit
this information

to be able to treat the cancers
that are pictured on the right.

We'd love to be
able to understand how we might use microbial
proteins to regulate

human biology and to improve
cancer treatment to therapy.

So taken together, our
relationship with our microbes is most certainly complicated.

Some of the microbes are bad. Some of the microbes are good. Sometimes it just
depends on if they're

in the wrong place
at the wrong time.  But we have lots
of opportunities,

now that we have sharp
and effective tools to measure microbes, to study
how they impact host health.

One of the most important
things that we do in our lab is collaborate broadly
across the world, as you heard in
the introduction.

I'm really proud and honored to
collaborate with the H3 Africa Genomics Consortium to improve
the study of microbiomes

and genomes all over the
world, not just in places where wealthy people live and
researchers happen to reside.

And so we've been very
fortunate to collaborate with Professor Hazelhurst, and
many others in South Africa,

to actually carry out some
of the first comprehensive microbiome analyzes of
individuals in Africa.

And I'm actually very excited,
because our first major paper on this or a set of
major papers on this

just came out over the
course of the last year, with the most recent paper
coming out two days ago.

We're interested in these
not only because of diseases like cancer, but as pictured
on the previous slide,

issues such as obesity
and heart disease have become of
increasing interest, not only in high income
countries like the United

States, but all over the world,
including in South Africa. So there our focus
has been on obesity

in women and
cardiometabolic disorders. Soon we actually plan
to study menopause.

As I mentioned before,
we're keen to figure out how microbial therapy might
boost cancer immunotherapy.

And I would be
remiss to not mention that we are also very keen to
understand the gut-brain axis,

focusing on a couple of major
diseases, Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease.

Finally, I'll just end
with a note about how

microbial genomes
are interesting, not only because they tell
us how microbes function,

but they also are
amazing treasure troves of cool enzymes and machinery.

I'm guessing that many
of you in the audience have heard about CRISPR,
which is basically a system.

The CRISPR Cas9
system is a system that exists in
bacteria to fight off phages, which are viruses
that infect bacteria.

This entire enzyme
system has been co-opted for genome editing. There are tons of
companies in this space.

And this type of
editing technology has enabled medical
practitioners

to fix errors in
people's genomes to try and reverse diseases.

Most recently, we and a set of
collaborators in the Bassik, Bintu, and Hsu labs
have worked together

to identify a new class
of genome editing enzymes from bacterial genomes.

This class had been previously
described in a limited way. These are the large
serine recombinases.

We've been able to
discover thousands of additional candidates and
identified the specific places

where they targeted
the genome, which might enable us and others to
take large amounts of DNA cargo

and deliver them to safe
places in the human genome, thereby treating people who
have complicated gene deletion

disorders. So we've talked
about a lot of things

today, ranging from who's
there in our microbiome, to how we measure them,
how microbes travel

between human bodies and within
a human body to cause problems. And we touched on how things
are moving in a new direction,

to try and better understand
microbial communication, so we can co-opt those
machineries to try and improve

modern medicine. There is a lot of
promise, as I'm sure you can appreciate,
and a lot more work to do.

I look forward to
hearing your questions. And I just want to end by
thanking my entire lab--

as I mentioned, I'm
very fortunate to work with an incredibly talented
and passionate group

of individuals-- our many collaborators,
our funding sources,

my recent grads, and of course,
all the patients and people who have participated
in our studies.

I look forward to
your questions. JACKIE PETERSON: Great. Thank you so much, Professor
Bhatt, for that presentation.

That was really fascinating. So for the first question,
"If a baby elephant

is inoculated by feeding on
parent species to acquire the microbiomes, what's the
mechanism that a human infant

uses to acquire microbiomes?" DR. AMI BHATT: Yeah,
great question. So it's been demonstrated
that infants actually

acquire their first
microbes during birth, which means that the microbiomes
of infants born

by vaginal delivery
are actually quite different from the
microbiomes of infants that are born by c-section.

It's been demonstrated that
in the very, very early part of life, infants actually--
or by vaginal delivery

are colonized with a
lot of vaginal microbes. And infants born by c-section,
it won't surprise you,

are colonized with a
lot of skin microbes. Over the course of time
however, infants probably

around them. A great mentor of
mine, Stan Falco,

who was a really world
famous microbiologist, used to joke that the world
is covered in a fecal veneer,

meaning that there are
microbes everywhere that are from the gut microbiome. And so there's probably a
little bit of that as well.

And so as babies
actually move on in life, they acquire microbes
from their environment.

And there's actually a very
standard process up along which the microbiome
builds, which

is actually super fascinating
and a topic in and of itself. JACKIE PETERSON: That's
really interesting.

Thank you. The next question is, "When the
microbes that are transferred

via FMT may go away
over time, is it because the native
microbiome has pathogens

in it that take over, or the
native microbiome just resets?" DR. AMI BHATT: This is
an excellent question

that we don't exactly
know the answer to yet. I would speculate
that what happens

is there are microbes from
the native microbiome, the original recipient
microbiome, that

are kind of lying in wait. And so they're suppressed
to very low levels. And over time, they can
actually increase in amount.

I also think that people
require probably their microbes from their environment.

I think part of the reason
that the donor microbes go away might be due to actual
warfare, which is

what you have described, right? They're being fought off by
the recipient microbiome.

Another reason that
they might go away is because of
lifestyle differences. So for example, I
happen to be vegetarian.

If I got a fecal
microbiota transplant from somebody who ate mostly
meat, a lot of their microbes

would not find a
happy home in me, because I wouldn't be
feeding them the right foods. And so I think that also
plays a role in figuring out

which microbes might
be able to stay for longer term, versus which
end up getting kicked out.

I also think that the
question you asked is very related to
the previous question. We talked about this
very orderly process

of microbiome assembly
that happens in infants. And if you think about
that really orderly process

like a pyramid, if
you take out a piece of the middle of
the pyramid, it's really hard to replace
it with a piece that's

a different size or shape. And so I think what
happens is our microbes are very dependent on each
other in a complex network.

And that's probably also
why the introduction of a few microbes
via FMT or probiotics

is unlikely to have
long-term effects, unless we keep on giving people
those microbes.

JACKIE PETERSON:
Great, thank you. The next question is,
"What are some good ways to improve and protect our
gut health and microbiomes?"

DR. AMI BHATT: So there
are several things that we can do to try and
improve our gut health and protect our microbiomes.

I think one thing that
is incredibly important is trying to eat a diverse diet. In fact, many different
diets have been studied.

And many have posited that
certain diets are better for the microbiome than others.

I think some of the most
convincing data on this comes from a study that found
that eating more than 30--

three-zero-- different types
of plants in a day, in a week, rather, is one of the
biggest predictors

of microbiome diversity. So I think keeping a diverse
diet is incredibly important.

Staying hydrated is
probably an important part of this equation. Many people do want to
take probiotics or eat

fermented foods. Obviously, many cultures
across the world have had long traditions
of fermented foods.

And I think that it's advisable. However, with probiotics,
it's hard to know what you're getting.

Probiotics aren't regulated
the same way medications that we take are. And so you never know if what's
on the label of the bottle

is actually what's in the
capsule that you're taking. Furthermore, as we
mentioned before, it's hard to know if
those microbes that you

take in probiotics will
really stick or not. So I think some of the
best things that one can do

is try to eat a
diverse diet to try to keep a relative diversity
of foods on your plate,

to stay well
hydrated, and to eat the types of fermented
foods that you enjoy.

JACKIE PETERSON:
Great, thank you.

Along those lines,
"Can knowledge of individual gut microbes
provide a personalized plan

for improved diet and
healthy lifestyles?" DR. AMI BHATT: So there are
many groups that are actually

trying to achieve this
objective of taking a look at your
microbiome and then trying to comment on what
might help you achieve a better

microbiome. I look at microbiomes
all day long. It's actually my job. And I'm also a physician.

And I've got to
say, I don't think the science is quite there yet. That said, there are
efforts that are underway, both on the research
side of the equation

and also on the industry
side of the equation, to try to help people
diversify their microbiomes.

I do think as we
look to the future, we will be able to better
and better understand the microbiome, to understand
what our microbes like to eat,

and think about ways
that we can feed them. Sometimes I like to
joke that we're not just eating for ourselves.

We're eating for trillions. And so knowing who's
in our gut microbiomes and what they like to eat
might help us actually modulate

and modify our microbiomes. I can certainly
tell you that one of the reasons I think
fibers are so important

is that simple sugars are
actually preferentially metabolized by most pathogens.

And so one way that
we can suppress the growth of pathogens
in the gut microbiome is really to try to
limit simple sugars.
JACKIE PETERSON: Excellent.

There is another question. "Is there a
significant difference in the health of
breastfed babies compared

to the health of
formula fed babies because of the differences
in their microbiomes?"

DR. AMI BHATT: And so this
has been extensively studied in the medical literature. In the microbiome
literature, while there

are differences in the
microbiomes of breastfed and formula fed babies
early on in life,

it's unclear whether
those changes actually persist in the long term. I mean, there's obviously
the intersection area, too.

There are a lot of babies
that are fed by both breast milk and formula. And so that remains another
kind of interesting area

for investigation. I think based on the data
that we have right now, the best answer I
could probably give

is that there are probably
no major long-term effects. There may be some subtle ones.

And in the setting where there
is extended formula feeding before the introduction
of solid foods,

there may be some consequences,
in terms of immune maturation. Because remember, those
early parts of life

are where the
microbiome is changing and the immune
system is growing. And so they're really
influencing one another.

I will say, one
last thought on this is that while in
the United States, for example, the practice
is not to introduce

complementary foods
or solid foods until around six
months of life, that

is actually very different
in different countries around the world. And so there are countries
where solid foods are

introduced very, very early on. And so I'd be very
curious to know how that impacts the growing gut
microbiome of babies as well.

JACKIE PETERSON: And
the next question is, "Are there any
other foods, in addition

to onions, that are beneficial
for good bacterial strains?"

DR. AMI BHATT:
Absolutely, I think basically any fibrous
food is a good choice. Jerusalem artichokes
have a ton of fiber.

Eating fruits with
the skins on-- so don't get rid of
that apple peel. Just wash your apple and eat it.

Leafy greens have a
lot of fiber as well. And it's interesting, all
of these different foods have different types of fiber.

Legumes also have a
wide variety of fibers. And so lentils have
different fibers,

from garbanzo beans, which have
different fibers from pinto beans. And so exploring a variety of
these different plant-based

foods can be extremely
helpful for bringing more fiber into your diet.

JACKIE PETERSON: And, "How
does cleanliness due to COVID affect the microbiome?"

DR. AMI BHATT: This has been a
topic of a lot of conversation. We have kids who have been in
much more hygienic homes, who

aren't interacting
with other kids, aren't interacting with
almost any other adults other than their parents.

I think the anticipation
is that this will have some impact on the microbiome. If you ask me to
guess, I would guess

that the impact is going to
be relatively small, just because it's so
difficult to live a totally clean, sterile life.

You know, so long as you're
going out there in the world, you're being exposed
to tons of bacteria. Places like soil,
for example, are just

teeming with bacteria--
way more microbes in soil per square or cubic
inch than in our guts.

And so I think it's
really difficult to limit our exposures entirely. But I do anticipate that as
this is studied in the years

to come, there will
be subtle changes. And I'm curious to see
the impact of this. I think that that
will not only be

important on the gut
microbiome side of things but possibly also on the skin
microbiome side of things.

And so we'll have
to wait to see. I do think on balance
though, we're always

weighing risks and benefits. And I think during
the period of time where there was so
much uncertainty,

certainly it was worth the
potential risk of deficits

in the microbiome to avoid the
sure risk of potential exposure to COVID for young and
unvaccinated children.
JACKIE PETERSON: Thank you.

"So do oncology nutritionists
recommend butyrate for patients with
graft-versus-host disease?"

DR. AMI BHATT: So butyrate
itself isn't recommended. And part of the reason
it isn't recommended is it really,
honestly just stinks.

Butyrate-- I can't
believe I'm going to say this on a webinar--
butyrate smells like farts. And so nobody wants to take.

It even mice don't
want to eat it. And that's part of why
this workaround has arisen, which is giving people fiber,
so that butyrate can be made

when the fiber is metabolized. The other challenge
is, of course, butyrate is actually
a small molecule,

if you remember what it looks
like, tiny, short-chain fatty acid. So it can also be
absorbed very high

in the GI tract, which means
that it may not get down to the parts of the intestine
where graft-versus-host disease

is important. But absolutely, it
has been investigated. People have thought
about are there

ways to formulate
butyrate into like a super olfactory-contained
capsule so people can take it.

But it hasn't quite
hit prime time yet.  JACKIE PETERSON: All
right, thank you.

Last question that we
have time for today, "Since you talked about
boosting regulatory T cells,

I imagine there have been
studies also regarding the microbiome and
inflammatory diseases,

specifically like ulcerative
colitis and Crohn's?" DR. AMI BHATT: And
so there have been

extensive studies on
ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, which
are two different flavors of inflammatory bowel disease.

These diseases, for those
who aren't familiar, are caused by our immune
systems attacking our guts.

And the two diseases
are slightly different from one
another but actually share some similarities. There have been, like I
said, extensive studies

in this regard. A lot of people have
actually postulated that fecal microbiota
transplant might

be helpful in changing
the microbiomes of these individuals to try
and increase regulatory T cell

proliferation and
suppress inflammation. That's actually some
of the work where

it's been found that
while a fecal microbiota transplantation might
help people for a while,

the effect seems to go away. And we wonder if our findings
that donor strains don't really

engraft for the
long-term might be responsible for this finding. And so there are
studies underway

with both fecal microbiota
transplant and probiotics, live bacterial
therapies, to give people

those therapies on a routine
basis to try and suppress inflammation. So I anticipate that
there will continue

to be exciting
research in this realm. I will say from a
physician perspective,

if we could find a way to find
the molecules that are actually responsible for modulating
the immune system

and doing much more than just
inducing T reg proliferation, I'd much rather develop those
molecules into medications

that we can give patients,
rather than taking the risk of giving
somebody a fecal microbiota

transplant filled with lots
of known and many more unknown bacteria, where I could possibly
be introducing a pathogen.

And so I would say
the field is really moving in the direction
of thinking about what the molecules are that
the microbes use to engage

in cross-talk and
then leveraging those as potential
drug-like compounds.
